subject: Re: [junit] Re: Mock objects, how to use them?
msgSnippet: ... Hash: SHA1 Hi, ... I can t see any censorship. ... Really. ... That s a really good idea. ... Service Provider Interface. ... Probably not. So you want to
messageBody:
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hi,


Am Dienstag, 8. April 2003 22:05 schrieb javainsel:
> Its strange that this forum uses censorship system before the
> postings appear.
I can't see any censorship.

> I was and am serious, all the time.
Really.

> Forget now about DbC. We can discuss about it later (in a few
> weeks/month) again.
That's a really good idea.

> Somehow I can't imagine to use Mock objects without our framework to
> support it.
> We are at the beginning in our company of creating ERP applications
> with the framework and the know how is not good yet.

> What means SPI?
Service Provider Interface.

> I just want to use Mock objects for the database. The test data must
> be coming
> from the test classes and not be inside the database. So we need
> Mock objects
> I think. But I don't know how to create them since I still don't
> know how
> our framework works inside and how Mock objects are used.
>
> Now you think it is not necessary that our framework supports Mock
> objects?
Probably not.
So you want to test your part of the code or the framework?
If you want to test your part of the code, let your mock objects implement the
interfaces and extend the stubs (abstract classes) of the framework.
If you want to test the framework, replace the JDBC parts by a mock
implementation.


Bye
- --
